revision.text:
{{About|Bristol Old Vic Theatre Company|the associated Theatre School|Bristol Old Vic Theatre School}} {{Use British English|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox Theatre |name = Bristol Old Vic Theatre Company |image = Bristol Old Vic (750px).jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = The theatre complex as it was prior to 2016 |address = King Street
BS1 4ED |city = [[Bristol]] |country = United Kingdom |designation = [[Grade I listed building]] |coordinates = {{coord|51.452|-2.594|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |architect = |owner = Trustees of the Theatre Royal |capacity = 540 (Theatre Royal)
188 (Weston Studio) |type = [[Repertory]] |opened = 1766 |yearsactive = |rebuilt = 1970–72; 2016-18 |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = |website = [http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk Bristol Old Vic] }} '''Bristol Old Vic''' is a British theatre company based at the '''Theatre Royal, Bristol'''. The present company was established in 1946 as an offshoot of the [[Old Vic]] in [[London]]. It is associated with the [[Bristol Old Vic Theatre School]], which became a financially independent organisation in the 1990s. Bristol Old Vic runs a Young Company for those aged 7–25.{{cite web|url=http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/bovyc.html |title=Education Overview |publisher=Bristol Old Vic |accessdate=23 February 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207084947/http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/bovyc.html |archivedate= 7 February 2009 |df= }} The Theatre Royal, the oldest continually-operating theatre in the English-speaking world, was built between 1764 and 1766 on [[King Street, Bristol|King Street]] in [[Bristol]].{{cite news|title=Bristol Old Vic Theatre marks 250th anniversary |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-36370411 |publisher=BBC |date=30 May 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530110701/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-36370411 |archivedate=30 May 2016 |df= }} The Coopers' Hall, built 1743–44, was incorporated as the theatre's foyer during 1970–72. Together, they are designated a Grade I [[listed building]] by [[Historic England]].{{cite web|title=THE THEATRE ROYAL, KING STREET (north side) |work=Images of England |url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=379885 |accessdate=8 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606125403/http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=379885 |archivedate= 6 June 2011 |df= }} [[Daniel Day-Lewis]] called it "the most beautiful theatre in England." In 2012 the theatre complex completed the first phase of a £19 million refurbishment, increasing the [[seating capacity]] and providing up to ten flexible performance spaces. Besides the main Theatre Royal auditorium, the complex includes the Studio theatre and the Side Stage, Paint Shop and Basement performance areas. Whilst the theatre was closed, the company continued to present work in the Studio and Basement spaces, as well as at other sites around Bristol. The Theatre Royal re-opened in 2012 with ''[[Wild Oats (play)|Wild Oats]]''. ==History of the theatre== The theatre is situated on [[King Street, Bristol|King Street]], a few yards from the [[Bristol Harbour|Floating Harbour]]. From 1972 until 2016, the public entrance was through the Coopers' Hall, the earliest surviving building on the site. The Coopers' Hall was built in 1744 for the Coopers' Company, the [[guild]] of [[cooper (profession)|cooper]]s in Bristol, by [[architect]] [[William Halfpenny]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/redevelopment.html |title=Redeveloping Bristol Old Vic |publisher=Bristol Old Vic |accessdate=13 March 2015 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302072022/http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/redevelopment.html |archivedate= 2 March 2015 |df= }} It has a "debased [[Palladian]]" façade with four Corinthian columns. It only remained in the hands of the Coopers until 1785, subsequently becoming a public assembly room, a wine warehouse, a Baptist chapel and eventually a fruit and vegetable warehouse.{{cite journal|last=Manser |first=José |date=1 December 1972 |title=Theatrical renaissance in Bristol |journal=Design |issue=288 |url=http://vads.ahds.ac.uk/diad/article.php?title=288&year=1972&article=d.288.30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903080052/http://vads.ahds.ac.uk/diad/article.php?title=288&year=1972&article=d.288.30 |archivedate= 3 September 2014 |df= }} The theatre was built between 1764 and 1766. The design of the auditorium has traditionally been taken to have been based, with some variations, on that of the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] in London.Mark Howell has shown that, when built, Bristol's New Theatre measured 6 rods (roughly 100ft) long and 3 rods (roughly 50ft) wide, comparable with the known dimensions of Drury Lane. Also like Drury Lane, open yard space, measuring between 5 and 20ft, surrounded the New Theatre on three sides.{{cite web|url=http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/resources/theatres/show/736-theatre-royal-bristol |title=Theatre Royal (Bristol) – The Theatres Trust |publisher=www.theatrestrust.org.uk |accessdate=8 April 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324064647/http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/resources/theatres/show/736-theatre-royal-bristol |archivedate=24 March 2009 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=100229&strquery=bristol%20theatre |title=The Theatre Royal – Buildings |publisher=British History Online |quote=Finally there is some measure of comparative evidence to be found in the Theatre Royal, Bristol, built in 1766 after the model of Drury Lane as it then existed, somewhat altered but still retaining many original features dating from 1674. At Bristol, the two superimposed boxes on either side of the stage are flanked by giant Corinthian pilasters, canted away from the proscenium, and constructed with more than a mere suggestion of perspective in the lines of the box parapets and the architrave of the now incomplete entablature. |accessdate=8 April 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020152752/http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=100229&strquery=bristol%20theatre |archivedate=20 October 2012 |df= }} Although Bristol architect [[Thomas Paty]] supervised construction, the theatre was built to designs by James Saunders, [[David Garrick]]'s carpenter at Drury Lane.{{cite news|last1=Thorpe |first1=Vanessa |title=Secrets of the rowdy past revealed as Bristol Old Vic reopens |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/sep/09/bristol-old-vic-reopens |accessdate=13 March 2015 |work=Guardian |date=9 September 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402222001/http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/sep/09/bristol-old-vic-reopens |archivedate= 2 April 2015 |df= }} Saunders had provided drawings for the theatre in Richmond, Surrey, built in 1765. A long section (1790, at Harvard University Theatre Collection) and a survey plan (1842, at the Local Studies Library) of the Richmond theatre show close similarities with the Bristol theatre in the proportions and in the relationship between the actors on stage and the spectators surrounding them on three sides.{{cite web|title=Bristol Old Vic Redevelopment |url=http://www.studioaba.co.uk/Andrzej_Blonski_Architects/Bristol_4_files/Phase%204.pdf |publisher=Andrzej Blonski Architects |accessdate=13 March 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402235934/http://www.studioaba.co.uk/Andrzej_Blonski_Architects/Bristol_4_files/Phase%204.pdf |archivedate= 2 April 2015 |df= }} The site chosen was Rackhay Yard, a roughly rectangular empty site behind a row of medieval houses and to one side of the Coopers' Hall. Two (and possibly three) new passageways built through the ground floor of the houses fronting King Street gave access to Rackhay Yard and the "New Theatre" inside it.{{cite book|last1=Howell|first1=Mark|title=Imaginative Genius: Spectators on Stage at Shakespeare's Playhouses & Bristol's Old Vic|date=2014|publisher=Mark Howell|isbn=9780992643713|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=avocBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT16&lpg=PT16&dq=Bristol+Old+Vic+Rackhay+Yard&source=bl&ots=BFS010F0WO&sig=alwGvdE09sbNXSomyqaBbP8RuJc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=sgUDVbm9OeO07gaqs4DYBA&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Bristol%20Old%20Vic%20Rackhay%20Yard&f=false}} The theatre opened on 30 May 1766 with a performance which including a prologue and epilogue given by David Garrick. As the proprietors were not able to obtain a Royal Licence, productions were announced as "a concert with a specimen of rhetorick" to evade the restrictions imposed on theatres by the [[Licensing Act 1737]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cla.purdue.edu/academic/engl/navsa/Conferences/2006/documents/MoodyCompanionfinals.doc|title=Theatrical Geographies and the Birth of a National Stage|last=Moody|first=Jane|pages=4–6|accessdate=19 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060905155149/http://www.cla.purdue.edu/academic/engl/navsa/Conferences/2006/documents/MoodyCompanionfinals.doc|archivedate=5 September 2006}} This ruse was soon abandoned, but a production in the neighbouring Coopers' Hall in 1773 did fall foul of this law. {{cite web |url=http://www.englandspastforeveryone.org.uk/Counties/Bristol/Projects/SlaveryTrail/Items/TheatreRoyal |title=England's Past for Everyone in Bristol : Theatre Royal (Trail Location 20) |publisher=www.englandspastforeveryone.org.uk |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121224100001/http://www.englandspastforeveryone.org.uk/Counties/Bristol/Projects/SlaveryTrail/Items/TheatreRoyal |archivedate=24 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Legal concerns were alleviated when the Royal [[Letters Patent]] were eventually granted in 1778, and the theatre became a [[patent theatre]] and took up the name "Theatre Royal". At this time the theatre also started opening for the winter season, and a joint company was established to perform at{{cite web|url=http://www.cla.purdue.edu/academic/engl/navsa/Conferences/2006/documents/MoodyCompanionfinals.doc|title=Theatrical Geographies and the Birth of a National Stage|last=Moody|first=Jane|page=10|accessdate=19 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060905155149/http://www.cla.purdue.edu/academic/engl/navsa/Conferences/2006/documents/MoodyCompanionfinals.doc|archivedate=5 September 2006}} both the [[Theatre Royal, Bath|Bath Theatre Royal]] and in Bristol, featuring performers such as [[Sarah Siddons]], {{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/first/j/jones-sisterhood.html |title=A Passionate Sisterhood |publisher=www.nytimes.com |quote=But she did take Southey to the theatre to see Mrs Siddons.... |accessdate=8 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090409163319/http://www.nytimes.com/books/first/j/jones-sisterhood.html |archivedate= 9 April 2009 |df= }} whose ghost, according to legend, haunts the Bristol theatre. The auditorium was rebuilt with a new sloping ceiling and gallery in 1800. After the break with Bath in 1819 the theatre was managed by [[William M'Cready the elder]], with little success, but slowly rose again under his widow Sarah M'Cready in the 1850s. Following her death in 1853 the M'Creadys' son-in-law James Chute took over, {{cite web |url=http://www.bris.ac.uk/theatrecollection/bristol.html |title=Bristol Theatre, Theatre Collection, University of Bristol |publisher=www.bris.ac.uk |accessdate=8 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906233042/http://www.bris.ac.uk/theatrecollection/bristol.html |archivedate= 6 September 2009 |df= }} but he lost interest in the Theatre Royal, which fell into decline when he opened the Prince's Theatre, originally known as the New Theatre Royal, {{cite web |url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatrecollection/bristol.html |title=Bristol Theatre, Theatre Collection, University of Bristol |publisher=www.bristol.ac.uk |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090710135216/http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatrecollection/bristol.html |archivedate=10 July 2009 |df= }} in 1867. A new, narrow entrance was constructed through an adjacent building in 1903. ==Formation of the Bristol Old Vic== [[Image:Bristol Old Vic interior.jpg|thumb|Interior of the main theatre]] Chute relinquished his lease on the Theatre Royal in 1861, concentrating his business at the Prince's Theatre, which was destroyed by [[The Blitz|bombing]] during the [[Second World War]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatre-collection/explore/theatre/peggy-ann-wood-archive/ |title=Peggy Ann Wood (1912–1998) |publisher=www.bristol.ac.uk |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506232028/http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatre-collection/explore/theatre/peggy-ann-wood-archive/ |archivedate= 6 May 2016 |df= }} In 1942 the lease owners put the building up for sale. {{cite web |url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatre-collection/explore/theatre/bristol-old-vic-company-archive/ |title=Bristol Old Vic, Theatre Collection, University of Bristol |publisher=www.bristol.ac.uk |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506205551/http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatre-collection/explore/theatre/bristol-old-vic-company-archive/ |archivedate= 6 May 2016 |df= }} The sale was perceived as a possible loss of the building as a theatre and a public appeal was mounted to preserve its use, and as a result a new Trust was established to buy the building. The Council for the Encouragement of Music and the Arts (CEMA) leased the building from the Trust and in 1946 CEMA's successor, the [[Arts Council]], arranged for a company from the London [[Old Vic]] to staff it, thus forming the Bristol Old Vic. Early members of the company included [[Peter O'Toole]] (making his first appearance in ''[[Major Barbara]]'' in 1956), [[John Neville (actor)|John Neville]], {{cite web |url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/51/John-Neville.html |title=John Neville Biography (1925–) |publisher=www.filmreference.com |accessdate=7 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416231353/http://www.filmreference.com/film/51/John-Neville.html |archivedate=16 April 2009 |df= }} [[Timothy West]], {{cite web |url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/73/Timothy-West.html |title=Timothy West Biography (1934–) |publisher=www.filmreference.com |accessdate=7 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100203071733/http://www.filmreference.com/film/73/Timothy-West.html |archivedate= 3 February 2010 |df= }} [[Barbara Leigh-Hunt]] {{cite web |url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/41/Barbara-Leigh-Hunt.html |title=Barbara Leigh-Hunt Biography (1935–) |publisher=www.filmreference.com |accessdate=7 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705085939/http://www.filmreference.com/film/41/Barbara-Leigh-Hunt.html |archivedate= 5 July 2009 |df= }} and [[Dorothy Tutin]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/participant.jsp?spid=195297&apid=41158 |title=Dorothy Tutin |publisher=www.tcm.com |quote=Tutin made her stage debut in 1949 and the following year joined the Bristol Old Vic Company |accessdate=7 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402085950/http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/participant.jsp?spid=195297 |archivedate= 2 April 2009 |df= }} The first artistic director was Hugh Hunt. {{cite web |url=http://www.bris.ac.uk/theatrecollection/bov.html |title=Bristol Old Vic Theatre Collection |publisher=University of Bristol |accessdate=23 February 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906190319/http://www.bris.ac.uk/theatrecollection/bov.html |archivedate= 6 September 2009 |df= }} An early triumph for the Bristol Old Vic occurred when the 1954 première production of ''[[Salad Days (musical)|Salad Days]]'' transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]] and became the longest-running [[musical theatre|musical]] on the London stage at that time. {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1521907/Julian-Slade.html |title=Julian Slade |publisher=Daily Telegraph |date=22 June 2006 |accessdate=7 April 2009 |last= |first= |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111104759/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1521907/Julian-Slade.html |archivedate=11 November 2012 |df= }} The Arts Council remained involved until 1963 when their role was taken over by the City Council. In the same year the London Old Vic was disbanded and the Bristol company became fully independent. The Bristol Old Vic also put plays on in the council-owned Little Theatre from then until 1980. A new theatre complex, designed by [[Peter Moro]], was completed in 1972. The 1903 entrance building was demolished, as were a number of surrounding buildings and, more controversially, the [[stage (theatre)|stage]] area of the 1766 theatre. A new stage and [[fly tower]] were built along with technical facilities and offices. The 150-seat New Vic studio theatre (later known as the Studio) was built in place of the old entrance, and the Coopers' Hall provided the theatre with the grand façade and foyer area it had previously lacked. Throughout the 1970s and 80s Bristol Old Vic productions were well received both locally and on tour, but by the late 80s faced chronic underfunding. A revival under the leadership of Andrew (Andy) Hay brought an increase in audience numbers;{{cite web|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/letters/feature.php/17209/a-tall-story-too-farr |title=A tall story too Farr |date=18 June 2007 |publisher=The Stage |accessdate=8 April 2009 |last=Smith |first=A. C. H. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121223158/http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/letters/feature.php/17209/a-tall-story-too-farr |archivedate=21 November 2008 |df= }} there followed a new Arts Council funding package, and in 2003 the appointment of joint [[artistic director]]s David Farr and Simon Reade.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/drama/3585736/Innovator-ready-for-a-fight.html |title=Innovator ready for a fight – Telegraph |publisher=telegraph.co.uk |date=13 November 2002 |accessdate=8 April 2009 |last=Christiansen |first=Rupert |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111104818/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/drama/3585736/Innovator-ready-for-a-fight.html |archivedate=11 November 2012 |df= }} They briefly branded the organisation the "new bristol old vic". In 2005 Reade became the sole artistic director.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2004/oct/21/theatre |title=Farr says bye to Bristol |date=21 October 2004 |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=7 April 2009 |last=Arendt |first=Paul |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140917045830/http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2004/oct/21/theatre |archivedate=17 September 2014 |df= }} Artistic highlights during these times included the production of A. C. H. Smith’s ''Up The Feeder, Down the Mouth and Back Again''{{cite news|title=Musical charts maritime history |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1411680.stm |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=1 February 2012 |date=28 June 2001 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031106165514/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1411680.stm |archivedate= 6 November 2003 |df= }} during Andy Hay’s tenure, and some well-received Shakespeare productions{{cite news|last=Gardner |first=Lyn |title=A Midsummer Night's Dream Review |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2003/may/15/theatre.artsfeatures |work=The Guardian |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=1 February 2012 |location=London |date=15 May 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911042809/http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2003/may/15/theatre.artsfeatures |archivedate=11 September 2014 |df= }} under David Farr and Simon Reade. ==Refurbishment== In July 2007, the board of trustees took the controversial decision to close the theatre for refurbishment.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/6645031.stm |title=Theatre shuts for refurbishment |publisher=BBC NEWS Bristol |date=10 May 2007 |accessdate=23 February 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070907192558/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/6645031.stm |archivedate= 7 September 2007 |df= }} Many members of the theatre profession feared for the future of the Old Vic.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/theatre/2007/05/is_the_bristol_old_vic_about_t.html |title=Is Bristol's Old Vic about to go dark for good? |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 May 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2007 |location=London |first=Lyn |last=Gardner |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070516130257/http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/theatre/2007/05/is_the_bristol_old_vic_about_t.html |archivedate=16 May 2007 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/16866 |title=ACE blamed for shock Bristol Old Vic closure |publisher=The Stage |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=2 December 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021024617/http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/16866 |archivedate=21 October 2007 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/17554 |title=Theatre stars demand Bristol Old Vic remains a producing company |publisher=The Stage |date=30 July 2007 |accessdate=2 December 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021025124/http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/17554 |archivedate=21 October 2007 |df= }} Following several public meetings in the winter of 2007/2008 a newly formed board of trustees appointed [[Dick Penny]], the director of the [[Watershed Media Centre]] as executive chairman.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/21365/bristol-old-vic-aims-for-2009-reopening |title=Bristol old vic aims for 2009 reopening |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007172657/http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/21365/bristol-old-vic-aims-for-2009-reopening |archivedate= 7 October 2008 |df= }} In February 2009 the company announced that [[Tom Morris (director)|Tom Morris]], at that time an associate director at the [[Royal National Theatre]] and formerly artistic director at [[Battersea Arts Centre]], had been appointed as artistic director.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/7908624.stm|title=New directors at Bristol Old Vic|publisher=BBC NEWS Bristol|date=25 February 2009|accessdate=25 February 2009|last=|first=}} {{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/theatreblog/2009/feb/24/tom-morris-bristol-old-vic-regional-theatre|title=Lyn Gardner: Tom Morris's role at Bristol Old Vic is crucial for all regional theatres|publisher=The Guardian|date=25 February 2009|accessdate=25 February 2009|last=Gardner|first=Lyn| location=London}} {{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/126663.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130131094759/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/126663.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=31 January 2013|title=Mamma Mia!'s Johnson Pens New Play for Bristol Old Vic; New Artistic and Executive Directors Appointed|publisher=Playbill|date=25 February 2009|accessdate=28 February 2009|last=Shenton|first=Mark}} [[Emma Stenning]], who had previously worked with Tom Morris at BAC, became executive director. In October 2010 there was a merger of the Old Vic and the Theatre Royal Bristol Trust, into a combined charity to be chaired by Laura Marshall, the managing director of [[Icon Films]].{{cite news |title=Trust merger 'will secure Vic's future' |author= |url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Trust-merger-secure-Vic-s-future/story-11229683-detail/story.html |newspaper=[[Bristol Evening Post]] |date=1 October 2010 |accessdate=8 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130505113428/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Trust-merger-secure-Vic-s-future/story-11229683-detail/story.html |archivedate=5 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }} [[Image:Coopers' Hall front.jpg|thumb|The Coopers' Hall served as the theatre's entrance from 1972 to 2016]] A fundraising campaign for the £19 million planned refurbishment was assisted by appearances from, among others, [[Richard Briers]], [[Stephanie Cole]], [[Judi Dench]], [[Prunella Scales]], [[Timothy West]] and [[Patrick Stewart]]. £5.3 million was provided by the Arts Council.{{cite news |title=£5.3m windfall for the Bristol Old Vic |author= |url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/163-5-3m-windfall-Bristol-Old-Vic/story-11310902-detail/story.html |newspaper=[[Bristol Evening Post]] |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=8 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130505063529/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/163-5-3m-windfall-Bristol-Old-Vic/story-11310902-detail/story.html |archivedate=5 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }} During the closure the company staged productions in the Studio theatre, the Basement and in other locations around Bristol, including Sally Cookson's adaptation of ''[[Treasure Island]]'' on King Street in summer 2011 and Melly Still’s revival of ''[[Coram Boy (play)|Coram Boy]]'' at the [[Colston Hall]] at Christmas 2011.{{cite web|title=Coram Boy |url=http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/index.php?id=1845 |publisher=Bristol Old Vic |accessdate=13 March 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402095630/http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/index.php?id=1845 |archivedate= 2 April 2015 |df= }} The plan was for a flexible theatre complex, where up to ten areas are available for performance. Tom Morris has cited as inspiration the [[Théâtre des Bouffes du Nord]] in Paris. The main auditorium gained an optional [[thrust stage]],{{cite news |title=Bristol Old Vic launches £19m plan to transform home |author=Alistair Smith |url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/28171/bristol-old-vic-launches-19m-plan-to |newspaper=[[The Stage]] |date=12 May 2010 |accessdate=8 February 2012 }} and an increase in seating to 540.{{cite news|title=Bristol Old Vic: Curtain up on a Georgian time capsule |author=Robert Gore-Langton |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-features/9506962/Bristol-Old-Vic-Curtain-up-on-a-Georgian-time-capsule.html |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=11 September 2012 |accessdate=21 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419054333/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-features/9506962/Bristol-Old-Vic-Curtain-up-on-a-Georgian-time-capsule.html |archivedate=19 April 2013 |df= }} The Side Stage area was redeveloped, with additional capacity of 250, creating the option of a separate second auditorium. Other spaces redeveloped as performance areas included the Paint Shop and the rehearsal room. The Theatre Royal re-opened in September 2012, with ''[[Wild Oats (play)|Wild Oats]]''. A further round of redevelopment was undertaken between June 2016 and September 2018. The street side of the 1970s Peter Moro building, containing the Studio theatre (originally the New Vic), was demolished and replaced by a new foyer with bar and box office, which makes a feature of the previously hidden theatre walls. The Coopers' Hall was adapted to house new performance and event spaces, including a studio theatre in the [[barrel vault]]s in its basement.{{cite web |title=Redevelopment |url=https://bristololdvic.org.uk/about/redevelopment |website=Bristol Old Vic |accessdate=1 November 2018}}{{cite web |title=Bristol Old Vic Theatre unveils £26m major refurbishment |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-45624225 |website=BBC News |accessdate=1 November 2018}} ==Touring== The Bristol Old Vic has a long history of taking productions on tour both within the [[United Kingdom]] and overseas. Notable production toured include ''[[Hamlet]]'', ''[[Arms and the Man]]'' and ''[[A Man for all Seasons]]'' to Ceylon and Pakistan in 1962–63; {{cite web |url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatrecollection/search/play_report?play_string=hamlet&season_select=all&theatre_select=Bristol+Old+Vic+Tour&image_view=Yes&query_image=&SUBMIT=Submit |title=Hamlet Tours, BOV |publisher=www.bristol.ac.uk |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419010101/http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatrecollection/search/play_report?play_string=hamlet&season_select=all&theatre_select=Bristol+Old+Vic+Tour&image_view=Yes&query_image=&SUBMIT=Submit |archivedate=19 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ''Hamlet'' and ''[[Measure for Measure]]'' to America, Holland and Belgium in 1966–67 and ''[[Man and Superman]]'' to the June [[Schauspielhaus Zürich| Schauspielhaus]] Festival in Zurich, 1958. {{cite web |url=http://www.bris.ac.uk/theatrecollection/search/play_report?play_string=man+and+superman&season_select=all&theatre_select=all&image_view=Yes&query_image=&SUBMIT=Submit |title=Man and Superman |publisher=www.bris.ac.uk |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419010101/http://www.bris.ac.uk/theatrecollection/search/play_report?play_string=man+and+superman&season_select=all&theatre_select=all&image_view=Yes&query_image=&SUBMIT=Submit |archivedate=19 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} The company has also made frequent visits to the [[Edinburgh International Festival|Edinburgh Festival]] and productions have toured to the [[Theatre Royal Bath]], [[Oxford Playhouse]], [[Royal Court Theatre]], London and the [[Young Vic]], London amongst others.{{cite book|last=Kemp|first=David|title=The Pleasures and Treasures of Britain|publisher=Dundurn Group|page=24|isbn=978-1-55002-159-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S7XyMa-n5_YC&pg=PA24&dq=Theatre+Royal+Bristol|accessdate=20 April 2009|year=1992}} Co-productions have taken Bristol Old Vic plays to most of Britain's major theatres.[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatrecollection/ University of Bristol Theatre Collection] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709093507/http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatrecollection/ |date= 9 July 2009 }}. Bristol Old Vic Collection. Programmes from Bristol Old Vic tours (1946–2002). Bristol Old Vic has co-produced with companies such as [[Kneehigh Theatre]], the [[Royal National Theatre]], [[West Yorkshire Playhouse]] and other regional theatres and companies across the UK. [[Tom Morris (director)|Tom Morris]]’ production of [[Swallows and Amazons]] transferred to the [[Vaudeville Theatre]] in London’s West End followed by a major UK tour. [[Simon Godwin]]'s production of [[Brian Friel]]’s [[Faith Healer]] is playing in the 2012 [[Hong Kong Arts Festival]]. Other recent touring productions include the Bristol Old Vic/[[Shakespeare at the Tobacco Factory]] co-production of [[Uncle Vanya]]. Bristol Old Vic's Ferment artist development strand also sees work developed at the theatre touring across the UK and internationally. ==Artistic directors of the Bristol Old Vic== {| class="wikitable" |- !Name !Period !Notable productions |- |Hugh Hunt{{cite book|last=Williamson|first=Audrey|author-link=Audrey Williamson (theatre critic)|author2=Landstone, Charles|title=The Bristol Old Vic – The First Ten Years|publisher=J Garnet Miller|location=London|year=1957|pages=30, 75}} |1946–1949 |[[The Beaux' Stratagem]], [[The Playboy of the Western World]], [[An Inspector Calls]], [[Romeo and Juliet]] |- |Allan Davis{{cite book|last=Williamson|first=Audrey|author-link=Audrey Williamson (theatre critic)|author2=Landstone, Charles|title=The Bristol Old Vic – The First Ten Years|publisher=J Garnet Miller|location=London|year=1957|page=78}} |1950 |[[Arms and the Man]], [[Julius Caesar (play)|Julius Caesar]] |- |Denis Carey{{cite book|last=Williamson|first=Audrey|author-link=Audrey Williamson (theatre critic)|author2=Landstone, Charles|title=The Bristol Old Vic – The First Ten Years|publisher=J Garnet Miller|location=London|year=1957|pages=85, 134–135}} |1950–1954 |[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]], [[Macbeth]], [[Un chapeau de paille d'Italie (play)|An Italian Straw Hat]], [[The Alchemist (play)|The Alchemist]] |- |John Moody{{cite book|last=Williamson|first=Audrey|author-link=Audrey Williamson (theatre critic)|author2=Landstone, Charles|title=The Bristol Old Vic – The First Ten Years|publisher=J Garnet Miller|location=London|year=1957|pages=136, 171}} |1954–1959 |[[The Crucible]], [[The Cherry Orchard]], [[Uncle Vanya]], [[The Recruiting Officer]], [[As You Like It]] |- |John Hale{{cite [[Rhinoceros (play)|Rhinoceros]], [[Richard II (play)|Richard II]] |- |[[Val May]] {{cite [[Hamlet]], [[The Italian Girl]], [[Uncle Vanya]] |- |[[Richard Cottrell]]{{cite Rubin {{cite web |url=http://www.east15.ac.uk/news-director.asp |title=East 15 Acting School at the University of Essex, News New Director |publisher=East 15 Acting School |accessdate=23 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722084235/http://www.east15.ac.uk/news-director.asp |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df= }} |1986–1987 |[[The Doctor's Dilemma (play)|The Doctor's Dilemma]] |- |[[Paul Unwin (film director)|Paul Unwin]] {{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/oct/11/theatre-television |title=Obituary: Peter Copley |date=11 Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]] |- |[[David Farr (theatre director)|David Farr]] and Simon Reade |2003–2005 |[[Loot (play)|Loot]] (Farr), [[The Odyssey]] (Farr), [[Private Peaceful]] (Reade) | |- |Simon Reade |2005–2007 |[[The Birthday Party (play)|The Birthday Party]] |- |[[Tom Morris (director)|Tom Morris]] |2009–present |Juliet and her Romeo, Swallows and Amazons, and The Crucible |}[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatrecollection/ University of Bristol Theatre Collection] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709093507/http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatrecollection/ |date= 9 July 2009 }}. Bristol Old Vic Collection. Bristol Old Vic brochures and papers. (1946–2002). ==Bristol Old Vic Theatre School== {{Main|Bristol Old Vic Theatre School}} The Bristol Old Vic Theatre School, opened by [[Laurence Olivier]] in 1946, is an affiliate of the [[Conservatoire for Dance and Drama]], {{cite web |url=http://www.cdd.ac.uk/affiliate-schools/ |title=Affiliate schools |publisher=Conservatoire for Dance and Drama |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303215841/http://www.cdd.ac.uk/affiliate-schools/ |archivedate= 3 March 2009 |df= }} an organisation securing the highest standards of training in the performing arts, and is an associate school of the [[University of the West of England]].{{cite web|title=The Bristol Old Vic Theatre School |url=http://enhanced.co.uk/sector-experience/charity-and-not-for-profit/bristol-old-vic-theatre-school/ |publisher=Enhanced |accessdate=13 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150307102405/http://enhanced.co.uk/sector-experience/charity-and-not-for-profit/bristol-old-vic-theatre-school/ |archivedate= 7 March 2015 |df= }} The School began life in October 1946, only eight months after the founding of its parent Bristol Old Vic Theatre Company, in a room above a fruit merchant's warehouse in the Rackhay near the stage door of the Theatre Royal. (The yard of the derelict St Nicholas School adjacent to the warehouse was still used by the Company for rehearsals of crowd scenes and stage fights as late as the early 1960s, notably for John Hale's productions of ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' starring the Canadian actor Paul Massie and [[Annette Crosbie]], a former student of the School, and [[Edmond Rostand|Rostand]]'s ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac (play)|Cyrano de Bergerac]]'' with [[Peter Wyngarde]]. Students from the Theatre School frequently played in these crowd scenes and fights.){{cite book|last=Brown|first=Shirley|title=Bristol Old Vic Theatre School: the first 50 years|publisher=Bristol Old Vic Theatre School|location=Bristol|pages=20–25|year=1996|edition=I|isbn=1-85459-395-1}} The School continued in these premises until 1954 when royalties from the musical, ''Salad Days'' by [[Julian Slade]] and Dorothy Reynolds were given to the School towards the purchase and conversion of two large adjoining Victorian villas in Clifton, which remain their base today.{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Shirley|title=Bristol Old Vic Theatre School: the first 50 years|publisher=Bristol Old Vic Theatre School|location=Bristol|pages=38–48|year=1996|edition=I|isbn=1-85459-395-1}} In 1995, that donation was formally recognised when a new custom-built dance and movement studio in the School's back garden was named the ''Slade/Reynolds Studio''.{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Shirley|title=Bristol Old Vic Theatre School: the first 50 years|publisher=Bristol Old Vic Theatre School|location=Bristol|page=186|year=1996|edition=I|isbn=1-85459-395-1}} The School provides comprehensive training courses for theatre, radio, film, and television professionals and its graduates are to be found in key positions as actors, directors, set designers, costumer designers, lighting designers and stage and company managers throughout the world. {{cite web |url=http://www.oldvic.ac.uk/training.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705093650/http://www.oldvic.ac.uk/training.html |archivedate=5 July 2008 |title=Training |publisher=www.oldvic.ac.uk |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= }} Among the most notable of the many distinguished actors on the School's list of alumni are the [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] winners [[Daniel Day-Lewis]] and [[Jeremy Irons]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.oldvic.ac.uk/past_graduates.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217040857/http://www.oldvic.ac.uk/past_graduates.html |archivedate=17 February 2008 |title=Past Graduates |publisher=www.oldvic.ac.uk |accessdate=19 April 2009 |last= |first= }} See [[:Category:Alumni of Bristol Old Vic Theatre School|Alumni of Bristol Old Vic Theatre School]]. === Peter O'Toole Prize === To coincide with their re-opening in 2012, the theatre launched an award called the Patron’s Prize, which was later renamed the [[Peter O’Toole]] prize following the actors death.http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/support.html#otooleprize {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150502034907/http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/support.html |date= 2 May 2015 }} The award is a six-month contract at the Bristol Old Vic offered to two graduating actors from the [[Bristol Old Vic Theatre School]].{{cite web|url=http://www.artsindustry.co.uk/latest-news/bristol-old-vic-revives-links/520 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208112758/http://www.artsindustry.co.uk/latest-news/bristol-old-vic-revives-links/520 |archivedate= 8 December 2015 |df= }} The inaugural winners were Emily May Smith and [[Isaac Stanmore]].{{cite web|url=http://www.artsprofessional.co.uk/news/theatrical-partnership-revived-bristol |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055034/http://www.artsprofessional.co.uk/news/theatrical-partnership-revived-bristol |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} {| style="width: 80%; height: 200px" border="1" class="wikitable" |+ Award Recipients and Productions Involved In ! Year ! Recipients ! Productions |- ! 2012 | Emily May Smith and [[Isaac Stanmore]]{{cite web|url=https://bristololdvictheatre.wordpress.com/2012/11/26/an-interview-with-emily-may-smith-and-isaac-s/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208234630/https://bristololdvictheatre.wordpress.com/2012/11/26/an-interview-with-emily-may-smith-and-isaac-s/ |archivedate= 8 December 2015 |df= }} || [[Wild Oats (play)|Wild Oats]], Does My Society Look Big In This? and Peter Pan |- ! 2013 | Martin Bassindale and Lindsay Dukes{{cite web|url=http://www.ayoungertheatre.com/feature-bristol-old-vic-theatre-schools-patrons-prize/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304133616/http://www.ayoungertheatre.com/feature-bristol-old-vic-theatre-schools-patrons-prize/ |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} | Great Expectations and The Little Mermaid |- ! rowspan="2" | 2014 | Jonathan Charles{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2014/winners-bristol-old-vics-peter-otoole-prize-announced/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304080701/https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2014/winners-bristol-old-vics-peter-otoole-prize-announced/ |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} | Juno and the Paycock |- | Bethan Nash and Millie Corser | Swallows and Amazons |} ==See also== {{Commons category|Bristol Old Vic}} *[[Bristol Old Vic Theatre School]] *[[Culture in Bristol]]{{Portal|Theatre}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Barker, Kathleen. ''The Theatre Royal Bristol 1766–1966: Two Centuries of Stage History'', The Society for Theatre Research, 1974 {{ISBN|0-85430-022-8}} * Barker, Kathleen. ''The Theatre Royal Bristol: The First Seventy Years'', Bristol Branch of the Historical Association, 1961 * Gomme, A., M. Jenner & B. Little, ''Bristol: an Architectural History'', Lund Humphries, 1979 * Howell, M. A. "Acting Space and Carpenters Tools," Around the Globe 47 (Dec. 2009), 34–35. * Howell, M. A. "Planning Theatres Under the Stage Licensing Act, 1737" Theatre Notebook 43.3 (1989) with publisher's errata in Theatre Notebook 44.1 (1990). * Ison, Walter. ''The Georgian Buildings of Bristol'', Kingsmead Press, 1952 * B. Little &, P. Moro, ''The Story of the Theatre Royal Bristol'', Trustees of the Theatre Royal, 1981 * Williams, Audrey and Charles Landstone, ''Bristol Old Vic—the First Ten Years'', J. Garnet Miller Limited, 1957 ==External links== *{{official website|https://bristololdvic.org.uk/}} *[http://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=1008195 Read a detailed historical record about Bristol Old Vic] *[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatre-collection/explore/theatre/bristol-old-vic-company-archive/ Bristol Old Vic archive at the University of Bristol Theatre Collection], [[University of Bristol]] *[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatre-collection/explore/theatre/kathleen-barker-archive/ Kathleen Barker archive at the University of Bristol Theatre Collection], [[University of Bristol]] *[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatre-collection/ Bristol theatre archives at the University of Bristol Theatre Collection], [[University of Bristol]] *[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/theatre-collection/explore/theatre/john-elvery-archive/ John Elvery archive at the University of Bristol Theatre Collection], [[University of Bristol]] *[http://www.lookingatbuildings.org.uk/cities/bristol/the-theatre-royal.html The Theatre Royal] at Looking at Buildings *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/bristol/hi/people_and_places/arts_and_culture/newsid_7867000/7867050.stm Behind the scenes at Bristol Old Vic – video report from BBC Bristol] {{Culture in Bristol}} {{Good article}} [[Category:Bristol Old Vic| ]] [[Category:Culture in Bristol]] [[Category:Grade I listed buildings in Bristol]] [[Category:Grade II* listed buildings in Bristol]] [[Category:Theatres in Bristol]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Bristol]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1766]] [[Category:Grade I listed theatres]] [[Category:Theatre companies in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Theatrical organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Music venues in Bristol]] [[Category:Producing theatres in England]] [[Category:History of Bristol]]

{{Infobox theatre |name = Broadway Theatre |image = File:Broadway Theatre 1912.png |caption = The Broadway Theatre on the left in 1912, playing ''Hanky Panky'' |address = 1445 Broadway |city = New York City |country = United States |designation = |coordinates = |architect = J.B. McElfatrick & Co. |owner = |capacity = |type = |opened = March 3, 1888 |yearsactive = |rebuilt = |closed = January 1929 }} [[File:Elsie Leslie as Little Lord Fauntleroy cph.3b10326.jpg|thumb|[[Elsie Leslie]] in ''[[Little Lord Fauntleroy]]'' (1888)]] [[File:Mr. Barnes of New York advertisement October 1888.png|thumb|right|Advertisement for an adaptation of ''[[Mr. Barnes of New York]]'', 1888]] The '''Broadway Theatre''' near 41st Street was a [[Manhattan]] theatre in operation from 1888 to 1929.<ref name="1929-one">(6 January 1929). [https://www.nytimes.com/1929/01/06/archives/the-broadway-theatre-passes-playhouse-build-by-james-bailey-partner.html The Broadway Theatre Passes; Playhouse Built by James Bailey, Partner of P.T. Barnum, Over Forty Years Ago Witnessed the Last Engagements of Booth and Irving and the Premiere of Ben Hur], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref> It was located at 1445 Broadway.
==History== [[James Anthony Bailey]], a circus manager and owner (the "Bailey" in [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus]]) started building the theatre in 1887 on the site of what had been the "Metropolitan Concert Hall" built in 1880. Bailey pulled out, and the project was completed by Frank Sanger, T.H. French, and E. Zborowski, with seating for about 1,800 and standing room for 500 more.<ref name="1929-one"/> The American premiere of ''[[La Tosca]]'' was performed on the theatre's opening night, March 3, 1888, featuring [[Fanny Davenport]]. It was not a great success, due in part to the [[Great Blizzard of 1888]] hitting New York ten days later, and it closed on April 28.<ref name="toscaends">(28 April 1888). [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1888-04-28/ed-1/seq-6/ Advertisement], ''[[The Sun (New York)]]'' (advertisement for last show on April 28, 1888 - Bloom book incorrectly says March 28; ''[[The Queen's Mate]]'' set to start on May 2)</ref>
The first successful run was ''[[Little Lord Fauntleroy]]'', with the title role alternately played by [[Elsie Leslie]] and Tommy Russell, which hit 100 showings on March 21, 1889.<ref name="1929-one"/> [[Lawrence Barrett]]'s final performance was at the theatre in March 1891, when he became ill during a performance of ''Richelieu''. [[Edwin Booth]]'s last New York performance occurred at the theatre that same month. ''[[El Capitan (operetta)|El Capitan]]'', [[John Philip Sousa]]'s most enduring operetta, opened here in 1896 before tours, revivals and a successful London run.<ref>[http://www.musicaltheatreguide.com/composers/sousa/elcapitain.htm ''El Capitan''], The Guide to Light Opera and Operetta, accessed December 4, 2015</ref> The highly successful ''[[Ben-Hur (play)|Ben-Hur]]'' debuted in November 1899, the greatest production which the theatre ever hosted.<ref name="1929-one"/> [[Mrs. Leslie Carter]], who later obtained fame with ''[[The Heart of Maryland (play)|The Heart of Maryland]]'', made her stage debut at the Broadway Theatre in 1890 in ''The Ugly Duckling''.
Starting around 1903, the theatre featured almost all musical productions. In 1913, after the closing of ''The American Maid'', the theatre was used for [[vaudeville]] and motion picture shows.
==Demise== The last performance was a vaudeville show called ''Broadway Fever'' in January 1929, and the theatre was soon after demolished.<ref name="1929-one"/><ref name="1929-two">(3 January 1929). [https://www.nytimes.com/1929/01/03/archives/final-curtain-rung-on-broadway-theatre-to-be-demolished-for-a.html Final Curtain Rung on Broadway Theatre; To Be Demolished for a Skyscraper, With Keith Vaudeville House, After 40 Years' Career], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref><ref name="bloom">Bloom, Ken. [https://books.google.com/books?id=fYbYyQjHwdsC&pg=PA84#v=onepage&q&f=false Broadway: Its History, People, and Places : an Encyclopedia 2d ed.], p. 84-85 (2004)</ref> The site is now occupied by the 33-story Bricken-Textile Building, built in 1929.<ref name="now">[https://books.google.com/books?id=80HCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA19#v=onepage&q&f=false New York Then and Now], p. 19 (2012)</ref>
In 1930, the former Colony Theatre on 53rd Street was renamed the [[Broadway Theatre (53rd Street)|Broadway Theatre]], which name it still retains.
==Notable productions== * ''[[Little Lord Fauntleroy]]'' (1888) * ''[[The Oolah]]'' (1889, 154 perf.) (starring [[Francis Wilson (actor)|Francis Wilson]])<ref name="bigrun">(6 October 1889). [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1889/10/06/100973921.pdf Francis Wilson, Manager; The Career of "The Oolah" and its Coming Tour in the Country], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref> * ''Castles in the Air'' (1890, 106 perf.) (starring [[DeWolf Hopper]]) * ''[[The Merry Monarch (musical)|The Merry Monarch]]'' (1890, return in 1891 after ''Wang'') (starring [[Francis Wilson (actor)|Francis Wilson]]) * ''[[Wang (musical)|Wang]]'' (1891, 151 perf.) (starring [[DeWolf Hopper]]) * ''[[Panjandrum (musical)|Panjandrum]]'' (1893, 156 perf.) (starring [[DeWolf Hopper]]) * ''Dr. Syntax'' (1894, 78 perf.)<ref name="syntaxone">(4 November 1894). [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1894/11/04/106878590.pdf Notes of the Stage], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (article notes 75th performance would be on November 15, play closed on Saturday November 17)</ref> * ''[[Madame Sans-Gêne (play)|Madame Sans-Gêne]]'' (1895, American premiere) * ''[[El Capitan (operetta)|El Capitan]]'' (1896, 112 perf.) * ''The Highwayman'' (1897, 144 perf.) * ''[[Ben-Hur (play)|Ben-Hur]]'' (1899) (194 perf.) * ''The Sleeping Beauty and the Beast'' (1901, 241 perf.) * ''The Silver Slipper'' (1902, 168 perf.) * ''The Prince of Pilsen'' (1903, 143 perf.) * ''The Yankee Consul'' (1904, 115 perf.) * ''[[Véronique (operetta)|Veronique]]'' (1905, 81 performances; American premiere) * ''The Vanderbilt Cup'' (1906, 143 perf.) * ''[[A Parisian Model]]'' (1906, 179 perf.) * ''[[Ein Walzertraum|A Waltz Dream]]'' (1908, 111 perf.) * ''[[The Midnight Sons]]'' (1909, 257 perf.) * ''The Jolly Bachelors'' (1910, 165 perf.) * ''The Summer Widowers'' (1910, 140 perf.) * ''The Hen-Pecks'' (1911, 137 perf.) * ''Hokey Pokey'' and ''Bunty Bulls and Strings'' (1912, 108 perf.) * ''Hanky Panky'' (1912, 104 perf.)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Broadway Theatre (41st Street)}} * {{Ibdb venue|id=1078|venue=Broadway Theatre}}

revision.comment: additional text, additional details and dates on brevet, cite Eicher; update brevet generals list link
revision.text:
[[Image:David Ramsey Clendenin.jpg|right|thumb|200px]] '''David Ramsay Clendenin''' (June 24, 1830 – March 5, 1895) was a teacher before the [[American Civil War]] and then a career [[United States Army]] officer from 1861 to 1891.<ref name=Eicher176>Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-3641-1}}. p. 176.</ref>
David Ramsay Clendenin was born in [[Little Britain, Pennsylvania]] on June 24, 1830.<ref name=Eicher176/> He moved to Illinois in 1850 and graduated from [[Knox College (Illinois)]] in 1854.<ref name=Eicher176/> He was a teacher until the outbreak of the American Civil War when in early 1861 he joined the District of Columbia Militia as a private.<ref name=Eicher176/> On September 18, 1861, he was appointed a [[Captain (United States O-3)|captain]] of the [[8th Illinois Cavalry]] and promoted to [[Major (United States)|major]] the same day.<ref name=Eicher176/> He was appointed [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]] of the regiment on December 5, 1862 and [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] on February 20, 1865.<ref name=Eicher176/>
Clendenin was one of 9 members of the military commission that tried and convicted the [[Assassination of Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln conspirators]] from May 8, 1865 to July 15, 1865.<ref name=Eicher176/> He was mustered out of the volunteers on July 17, 1865.<ref name=Eicher176/>
On January 13, 1866, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Andrew Johnson]] nominated Clendenin for appointment to the grade of brevet [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] of volunteers, to rank from July 11, 1865, and the [[United States Senate]] confirmed the appointment on March 12, 1866.<ref>Eicher, 2001, p. 742.</ref>
Clendenin was appointed major of the 8th United States Cavalry Regiment on January 22, 1867, lieutenant colonel of the 3rd United States Cavalry Regiment on November 1, 1882 and colonel of the 2nd United States Cavalry Regiment on October 20, 1888.<ref name=Eicher176/> He retired from the United States Army on April 20, 1891.<ref name=Eicher176/>
David Ramsay Clendenin died March 5, 1895 at [[Oneida, Illinois]].<ref name=Eicher176/> He is buried in Oneida Cemetery.<ref name=Eicher176/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== {{portal|American Civil War}} *[[List of American Civil War brevet generals (Union)]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Clendenin, David Ramsay}} [[Category:1830 births]] [[Category:1895 deaths]] [[Category:Union Army generals]] [[Category:United States Army colonels]] [[Category:People associated with the assassination of Abraham Lincoln]]

{{see also|List of countries by traffic-related death rate}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}}
[[File:Road_traffic_accidents_world_map_-_Death_-_WHO2012.svg|thumb|right|upright=1.35|Deaths for road [[traffic collision]]s per 100,000 inhabitants in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Road_traffic_accidents_world_map_-_Death_-_WHO2012.svg |title=WHO Disease and injury country estimates |year=2014 |work=World Health Organization |accessdate=15 Jul 2016}}</ref>{{refbegin|3}} {{legend|#b3b3b3|no data}} {{legend|#ffff65|less than 5}} {{legend|#ffdc00|5-10}} {{legend|#ffc600|10-15}} {{legend|#ffb000|15-20}} {{legend|#ff9a00|20-25}} {{legend|#ff6e00|25-30}} {{legend|#ff5800|30-35}} {{legend|#ff2c00|35-40}} {{legend|#cb0000|more than 40}} {{refend}}]] [[File:Traffic related deaths - Road fatalities per vehicle-km.svg|thumb|upright=1.35|Road fatalities per 1 billion vehicle-km in 2004 {{refbegin|3}} {{legend|#b3b3b3|no data}} {{legend|#ffff65|< 5.0}} {{legend|#fff200|5.0-6.5}} {{legend|#ffdc00|6.5-8.0}} {{legend|#ffc600|8.0-9.5}} {{legend|#ffb000|9.5-11.0}} {{legend|#ff9a00|11.0-12.5}} {{legend|#ff8400|12.5-14.0}} {{legend|#ff6e00|14.0-15.5}} {{legend|#ff5800|15.5-17.0}} {{legend|#ff4200|17.0-18.5}} {{legend|#ff2c00|18.5-20.0}} {{legend|#cb0000|> 20.0}}{{refend}}]] Worldwide it was estimated that 1.25 million people were killed and many millions more were injured in [[motor vehicle collisions]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/gho/road_safety/mortality/traffic_deaths_number/en/ |title=Number of road traffic deaths |date= |author= World Health Organization |accessdate=15 Jul 2016}}</ref> This makes motor vehicle collisions the leading cause of [[death]] among young adults of 15–29 years of age (360,000 die a year) and the ninth cause of death for all ages worldwide.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Global status report on road safety 2015|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/189242/1/9789241565066_eng.pdf|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=Jul 15, 2016}}</ref> In the [[United States]], 32,675 people died and 2.3 million were injured in crashes in 2014,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhtsa.gov/About+NHTSA/Press+Releases/2015/2014-traffic-deaths-drop-but-2015-trending-higher |title=Traffic fatalities fall in 2014, but early estimates show 2015 trending higher|publisher=National Highway Traffic Safety Administration |accessdate=15 Jul 2016}} </ref> and around 2,000 kids under 16 years old die every year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/810853|title=Comparison of Crash Fatalities by Sex and Age Group|last=Dow Chang|first=|date=|website=nhtsa.dot.gov|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131040939/https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/810853|archive-date=2017-01-31|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> It is estimated that motor vehicle collisions caused the deaths of around 60 million people during the 20th century,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.medcrunch.net/death-20th-century-infographic/ |title=Death in the 20th Century. The Infographic |date=Apr 2, 2013 |author= ROBERTA PESCE |accessdate=}}</ref> around the same as the number of [[World War II casualties]].
At worldwide level, traffic accidents is the main cause of violent death.<ref>http://www.roneurosurgery.eu/atdoc/CiuchilanElena_Epidemiology_f.pdf</ref>
==History and trends== [[File:US traffic deaths per VMT, VMT, per capita, and total annual deaths.png|thumb|upright=1.35|Annual US traffic fatalities per billion [[vehicle miles traveled]] (red), miles traveled (blue), per one million people (orange), total annual deaths (light blue), VMT in 10s of billions (dark blue) and population in millions (teal), from 1921 to 2017]] {{see also|Automobile safety#Safety trends|List of motor vehicle deaths in U.S. by year}}
Since the first decades of the 20th century, industrialized countries have seen the problem of traffic accidents rising <ref>http://www.roneurosurgery.eu/atdoc/CiuchilanElena_Epidemiology_f.pdf</ref>
Road toll figures in developed nations show that car collision fatalities have declined since 1980. Japan is an extreme [[List of motor vehicle deaths in Japan by year|example]], with road deaths decreasing to 5,115 in 2008, which is 25% of the 1970 rate per capita and 17% of the 1970 rate per vehicle distance travelled. In 2008, for the first time, more pedestrians than vehicle occupants were killed in Japan by cars.<ref>[http://www.japantoday.com/category/national/view/pedestrians-become-chief-victims-of-road-accident-deaths-in-2008 Pedestrians become chief victims of road accident deaths in 2008] {{webarchive|url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090725140530/http://www.japantoday.com/category/national/view/pedestrians-become-chief-victims-of-road-accident-deaths-in-2008 |date=25 July 2009 }}</ref> Besides improving general road conditions like lighting and separated walkways, Japan has been installing [[intelligent transportation system]] technology such as stalled-car monitors to avoid crashes.
In developing nations, statistics may be grossly inaccurate or hard to get. Some nations have not significantly reduced the total death rate, which stands at 12,000 in Thailand in 2007, for example.<ref>[http://en.thaihealth.or.th/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=133&Itemid=1 365 Days for Stopping Accident Deaths]</ref>
In the United States, twenty-eight states had reductions in the number of automobile crash fatalities between 2005 and 2006.<ref>[http://www.autoaccidentattorneys.net/injuries/auto-death-state.html People Killed in Motor Vehicle Crashes, by State, 2005-2006]</ref> 55% of vehicle occupants 16 years or older in 2006 were not using [[seat belts]] when they crashed.<ref>{{cite book | title = NCSA Research Note (DOT-HS-810-948) | publisher = US [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] |date=May 2008}}</ref>
Road fatality trends tend to follow [[Smeed's law]],<ref name=smeed>{{cite web | url = http://www.geog.ucl.ac.uk/~jadams/PDFs/smeed%27s%20law.pdf | format = PDF | first = John | last = Adams | publisher = [[University College London]] | title = Smeed's Law : some further thoughts }}</ref> an empirical schema that correlates increased fatality rates per capita with [[traffic congestion]].
==Deaths== [[File:Road-way vs. railway safety.png|thumb|300px|right|According to [[Eurostat]] the automobile is one of the less safe means of transport, if safety is measured as the less number of fatalities per travelled distance. Based on data by EU-27 member nations, 2008-2010.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/portal/page/portal/transport/data/database| type=statistical database| title=Statistics database for transports| date=20 April 2014| website=epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu| publisher=Eurostat, European Commission| accessdate=12 May 2014| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603163108/http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/portal/page/portal/transport/data/database| archivedate=3 June 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.era.europa.eu/Document-Register/Documents/SPR%202013%20Final%20for%20web.pdf| title=Intermediate report on the development of railway safety in the European Union 2013| editor=Vojtech Eksler| format=PDF| type=report| website=era.europa.eu| date=5 May 2013| page=1| publisher=Safety Unit, European Railway Agency & European Union| accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref>]] Crashes are categorized by what is struck and the direction of impact, or impacts. These are some common crash types, based on the total number that occurred in the U.S.A. in 2005, the percentage of total crashes, and the percentage of fatal crashes:<ref>National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Traffic Safety Facts 2005, 2007, P. 54. http://www-nrd.nhtsa.dot.gov/Pubs/810631.pdf</ref>
* [[Rear-end collision|Rear impacts]] (1,824,000 crashes, 29.6% of all US crashes, 5.4% of US fatal crashes) * [[Side collision|Angle or side impacts]] (1,779,000 crashes, 28.9% of all US crashes, 20.7% of US fatal crashes) * [[Run-off-road collision]]s (992,000 crashes, 16.1% of US crashes, 31.7% of US fatal crashes) * Collisions with animals (275,000 crashes, 4.5% of US crashes, 0.4% of fatal crashes) * [[Rollover]]s (141,000 crashes, 2.3% of all US crashes, 10.9% of US fatal crashes) * [[Head-on collision]] (123,000 crashes, only 2.0% of all US crashes, but 10.1% of US fatal crashes) * Collisions with pedestrians and bicyclists (114,000 crashes, only 1.8% of US crashes, but 13.5% of US fatal crashes) * [[Back-up collision]]s killed 221 people in the US in 2007, and injured about 14,400. This is one of the most common types of non-traffic auto collision in which road workers and children 15 and younger are killed.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/12/automobiles/12VIEW.html?ref=automobiles ''The Risk of Reverse'']. ''[[The New York Times]]'' 10 April 2009.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/pdfs/01-128.pdf |title=Building Safer Highway Work Zones: Measures to Prevent Worker Injuries From Vehicles and Equipment }} [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|NIOSH]], April 2001.</ref>
Rollover, head-on, pedestrian, and bicyclist crashes combined are only 6.1% of all crashes, but cause 34.5% of traffic-related fatalities.
Sometimes the vehicles in the collision can suffer more than one type of impact, such as during a shunt or high-speed spin. This is called a "second harmful event," such as when a vehicle is redirected by the first crash into another vehicle or fixed object.
